description: State-level harvest timing data from official agriculture department sources

FL.name: Florida
FL.department: Florida Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services

sources.title: Buy Fresh From Florida - Crops in Season (Web)
Florida Planting Guide (Growin' Crazy Acres)
sources.notes: Planting calendar - inverse validation. Shows WHEN to plant to achieve harvest windows. Planting Date + Days to Maturity = Harvest validation.

FL.triangulationNote: Multiple official sources confirm harvest windows. Planting guide provides inverse validation (when to plant to achieve those harvests). Web page is regularly updated, PDFs are point-in-time snapshots.

zones.usda_map_source: USDA Plant Hardiness Zone Map (1976-2005 data)
zones.zone_gradient: Florida spans USDA zones 8a (Panhandle) to 11a (Keys) - 7 zone transition across ~450 miles
zones.mapping_note: State agricultural zones correlate directly with USDA zone numbers: Zone 8 = North, Zone 9 = Central, Zone 10 = South, Zone 11 = Keys (only true tropical zone in continental US)

8.name: North Florida
8.notes: Similar growing patterns to Georgia/South Carolina. Cannot support year-round production of warm-season crops. Hard freezes occur.

9.name: Central Florida
9.notes: Citrus belt. Extended growing seasons but not fully tropical. Rare freezes can damage sensitive crops.

10.name: South Florida
10.climate: Subtropical, frost-free or extremely rare frost
10.notes: Year-round production of warm-season crops. Winter vegetable capital of USA. Commercial agriculture dominates.

11.name: Florida Keys
11.notes: Only true tropical zone in continental US. Can grow tropical fruits that won't survive in Zone 10 (mango, papaya, key lime). Limited commercial agriculture due to isolation and water scarcity.

tomato.notes: Year-round production with winter peak. Major growing regions: Southwest Florida, East Coast

8.notes: Two distinct seasons, no winter production due to frost

10.notes: Year-round potential, peak winter production for commercial market

11.notes: True tropical zone, year-round production possible. Limited commercial tomato production due to water/land constraints.

strawberry.notes: Winter crop. Plant City is the 'Winter Strawberry Capital'. Varieties: Florida Brilliance, Sweet Sensation

blueberry.notes: Early spring harvest. Rabbiteye and Southern Highbush varieties dominate

pepper.notes: Bell and specialty peppers year-round with winter-spring peak

sweet_corn.notes: Cool season crop in Florida. Multiple plantings for extended harvest

watermelon.notes: Spring to early summer. Florida is major early-season supplier to eastern US

citrus_orange.notes: Navel: Nov-Feb, Valencia: Feb-Jun. Multiple varieties extend season

citrus_grapefruit.notes: Peak winter fruit. White and red varieties

regionalNotes.southwest: Major production region: Lee, Collier, Hendry counties. Tomatoes, peppers, specialty crops
regionalNotes.eastCoast: Indian River region: Citrus. Palm Beach County: Winter vegetables
regionalNotes.central: Plant City (Hillsborough): Strawberries. Polk County: Citrus
regionalNotes.north: Limited commercial production, more small farms and U-pick operations

sources.title: California Fruits and Vegetables Seasonal Chart
Harvest Of The Month Produce List

apple.notes: Available year-round via storage, with slight dip in spring quality

strawberry.notes: Peak Apr-Jun, up to 10 million pint baskets shipped daily during peak

cherry.notes: California cherries early in national supply chain

peach.notes: First peaches late April from Salton Sea region

avocado.notes: California avocados arrive April, continue through fall

artichoke.notes: Peak spring, extending into early summer

regionalNotes.centralValley: Major production: stone fruit, tomatoes, grapes, nuts
regionalNotes.saltonSea: Earliest stone fruit in nation (late April)

citrus_orange.notes: Navel, Temple, Valencia oranges from Rio Grande Valley

citrus_grapefruit.notes: Texas Ruby Red from Rio Grande Valley

watermelon.notes: Texas is top US producer, early May through October

regionalNotes.rioGrandeValley: Winter citrus capital, South Texas produce

MI.name: Michigan
MI.department: Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development

cherry_tart.notes: Michigan is nation's top producer of tart cherries

blueberry.notes: Early blueberries June, sweeter through season until Labor Day

apple.notes: Late August start, fall is quintessential Michigan apple season

strawberry.notes: June strawberries signal start of berry season

grape.notes: Fall grape harvest supports Michigan wine industry

regionalNotes.westMichigan: Fruit belt along Lake Michigan - cherries, blueberries, apples

NY.name: New York
NY.department: New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets

sources.title: From Apples to Zucchini - NY Produce Guide

apple.notes: Late August to mid-November, NY is 2nd largest apple producing state

cherry.notes: Late June to mid-July, Hudson Valley orchards

grape.notes: Finger Lakes region, wine grapes and table grapes

regionalNotes.hudsonValley: Apples, stone fruit, berries - major orchard region

sources.title: Farm to Table PA Seasonal Calendar

apple.notes: Late July to early November, apples grown in every PA county

peach.notes: Peak July-August, Adams County major producer

strawberry.notes: June berries herald start of berry season

raspberry.notes: Red raspberries early August to early October

grape.notes: Late summer to early fall, Erie grape belt

regionalNotes.adamsCounty: Pennsylvania's fruit bowl - apples, peaches, cherries
regionalNotes.southeasternPA: Early season due to warmer climate

sources.title: Ohio Farm Bureau What's In Season

apple.notes: Early varieties Aug 10, main season Sep-Oct

regionalNotes.northernOhio: Later season due to cooler temps

peach.notes: Georgia peaches - May through September, peak July-August. Cultivars: Loring, Red Haven, Georgia Belle, Alberta

regionalNotes.peachCounty: Fort Valley area - historic peach belt

apple.notes: Washington is #1 US apple producer, Yakima/Wenatchee valleys

cherry.notes: Pacific NW cherry season June-August, major producer

peach.notes: Stone fruit production in Yakima Valley

regionalNotes.yakimaValley: Tree fruit capital - apples, cherries, stone fruit

sources.title: NC Fruit and Vegetable Availability Chart
NC State Extension Seasonal Availability Calendar

strawberry.notes: Late April through early June, peak in May

apple.notes: Western NC hub - Hendersonville apple festival. Storage extends to February

regionalNotes.westernNC: Apple country - Hendersonville area, mountain climate
regionalNotes.piedmont: Diverse production, tobacco transition to produce

apple.notes: Aug-Nov harvest, storage extends to March

pear.notes: Bartlett first, winter varieties through October

cherry.notes: Mid-June through July, Hood River area

blackberry.notes: Marionberry developed at OSU, late June-September

regionalNotes.hoodRiver: Cherry and pear capital, Columbia Gorge

VA.name: Virginia
VA.department: Virginia Department of Agriculture and Consumer Services

apple.notes: Multiple varieties, storage apples through December

peach.notes: Freestone varieties Jul-Sep, peak late July

strawberry.notes: April start possible, peak May in Central VA

raspberry.notes: Two peaks - June and mid-Aug to Sep

apple.notes: Aug-Oct, varieties include Honeycrisp, Fuji, Gala

blueberry.notes: NJ is major blueberry producer, late June-early August

cranberry.notes: NJ is #3 cranberry producer, Pine Barrens
MA is #2 cranberry producer, Cape Cod area

blueberry.notes: Native to MA, early July through late August

WI.name: Wisconsin
WI.department: Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade and Consumer Protection

apple.notes: Door County and Gays Mills (Apple Capital of WI)

cherry_tart.notes: Door County Montmorency cherries, mid-late July

cranberry.notes: WI is #1 cranberry producer, central Wisconsin marshes

sources.title: Minnesota Grown What's In Season Chart

apple.notes: Honeycrisp developed at UMN, late summer to fall

sources.title: Indiana Fruits and Vegetable Harvest Calendar

apple.notes: July 15 - Nov 1, Gala ready by 3rd week of August

peach.notes: Palisade peaches famous, arrives ~July 4, peak late Aug

cherry.notes: Bing and Rainier, mid-June to mid-July, short window

apple.notes: Mid-Aug start, North Fork Valley harvest to December

melon.notes: Rocky Ford melons famous, early Aug to mid-Sep

regionalNotes.palisade: Peach capital, Western Slope fruit region

blueberry.notes: Late May through August, peak May-June

sources.title: Certified SC Grown What's In Season

peach.notes: SC famous for peaches, late May through August, peak Jun-Jul

Regional notes capture important sub-state geographic distinctions
